Message.Title: Shorts, AMZN is heading towards 280.
Message.Msg: Unless the general market crashes. Are you sure the general market is going to crash anytime soon?

The points made here are valid but the metrics are even worse than you have stated. 1.) at June 30, 2012, AMZN may have $5B in cash but it has less than $1B in working capital (and this includes $4B in inventory at full acquisition cost.) In other words, AMZN has $5B in cash only because, at 6/30/12, it owed vendors and employees $11B. 2.) the CAPEX is way UNDERSTATED because the company has been using operating leases to fund fixed asset investment. I believe at June 30, 2012, AMZN has some $4B in operating lease obligations. I'm not saying the company is broke but the stock price is definitely way ahead of its underlying value and is facing headwinds: A) Working Capital issues can be solved with 1) free net cash flow which is good for the stock 2) or the issuance of debt or equity which is not good for the stock. B.) Operating Leases: I'm sure the AMZN treasury dept. is receiving ridiculously favorable lease terms from the knuckle heads in the bank leasing groups - so it probably makes sense for AMZN to lease finance fixed assets; however, don't underestimate how this manipulates the accounting and financial metrics. The $4B operating lease obligation is not on the balance sheet nor are the fixed assets. These additions to service centers, warehouse & distribution centers, servers, etc... do not run through CAPEX in the statement of cash flows. The operating leases are fully spelled-out in the 10Q notes along with the other $2B in debt obligations. So, arguably at 6/30/12, the company has $0 cash and $4B of off balance sheet fixed assets and liabilities.
Could be summed up in 3 concise words: It's a pig....

Message.Title: Pay Attention
Message.Msg: to insiders who have been selling at a fast pace. Don't assume you are smarter than they.

Insiders have received lots of stock as part of their compensation. So just because they sell, doesn't mean they believe the stock will go down. They're just being smart. But, if you sell now you'll miss out when it hits $300 later this year.
AMZN will not hit 300 this decade. Insiders are not to be ignored. The facts show that. Look at history. If you want to sell at 300, wait to buy at 150 or less.
Keep it up! You're an excellent reverse baramoter! I've done real well doing the opposite of what you suggest.
